question: Which university did Bonnie B. McConnell attend?

content.source_1:
Here is a potential Wikipedia entry for Bonnie B. McConnell:

Bonnie B. McConnell

Bonnie B. McConnell is an American ethnomusicologist and health educator. Early Life and Education

McConnell attended the University of Washington, a public research university in Seattle, Washington, United States. [1] During her time at the university, she developed a strong foundation in music and education, which would later inform her work as an ethnomusicologist and health educator. Career

As an ethnomusicologist, McConnell has made significant contributions to the field of music and culture. Her research has focused on the intersection of music and health, and she has worked with diverse communities to promote cultural understanding and exchange. In addition to her work as an ethnomusicologist, McConnell is also a health educator. She has developed and implemented health education programs that incorporate music and the arts to promote health and wellness. References

[1] University of Washington Alumni Directory.
content.source_2:
Bonnie B. McConnell

Bonnie B. McConnell is a renowned ethnomusicologist and health educator, recognized for her groundbreaking research on the therapeutic applications of traditional music in African cultures. Early Life and Education

McConnell was born on February 12, 1965, in Chicago, Illinois. She developed an interest in music and culture at a young age, which led her to pursue higher education in ethnomusicology. In 1985, McConnell enrolled at the Université de Kinshasa, a public university in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), where she spent two years studying the rich musical heritage of the region. During her time at the Université de Kinshasa, McConnell was deeply influenced by the works of Congolese musicologists, such as Joseph Kabasele and Nicolas Kasanda. Her research focused on the role of music in traditional healing practices, which laid the foundation for her future work in health education. Studies and Research

McConnell's research at the Université de Kinshasa culminated in her seminal paper, "Rhythms of Healing: An Exploration of Traditional Music in Congolese Health Practices" (1987). This study, published in the Journal of Ethnomusicology, examined the use of music in traditional healing ceremonies and its potential applications in modern healthcare. In the following years, McConnell continued to build upon her research, conducting extensive fieldwork in rural Congolese communities. Her work led to the development of innovative music-based health programs, which have been implemented in various African countries. References

* McConnell, B. B. (1987). Rhythms of Healing: An Exploration of Traditional Music in Congolese Health Practices. Journal of Ethnomusicology, 31(2), 123-145. * Kabasele, J. (1972). La Musique Congolaise: Une Étude sur les Origines et l'Évolution de la Musique Traditionnelle au Congo. Kinshasa: Éditions Université de Kinshasa. * Kasanda, N. (1980). Le Rôle de la Musique dans les Cérémonies Traditionnelles au Congo. Revue de Musicologie, 66(1), 34-50. External Links

* Université de Kinshasa: Official Website
* Journal of Ethnomusicology: Official Website
